content: this is dmg and we're going to be talking about how to paint water effects
okay so painting simple water effects this is a method dye procured from DM
Scotty on the DMS craft with some slight modifications so what I do is I take
whatever is going to be in the water which in this case of the pylons from
the bridge and I just mark out where that's going to be so just had the
bridge on there measured around and there now I'm just going to create where
those pylons will actually be in the water double check the placement now I
just start to draw concentric circles of spirals out from those points so that
will form the ripples these are merely as a guide to where I'm going to place
hot glue which will form the actual ripples itself so I just start to make
you know just lines as to where each ripple will be and so I can see more or
less what the pattern is going to look like before I actually apply the glue so
then get the glue nice and hot and start from the small areas where the pylons
will going or rocks or whatever you may have in the water and just start to go
around in circles so I we're not finished with the glue I
just sort of dab it down there you will see there will be a few wisps that
appear basically just to get rid of those you wait till the glue dries and
you rub it with your fingers and those whistle come off far easier so I've just
sped it up a bit just to show you and as it going around and the concentric
circles and following where all the lines are to get that sort of rippled
water look so these will form the actual ripples of the water but then use the
paint to generate the color as we'll see now and you know it's a relatively
simple process okay so I've just put the bridge on
there to check that that's working that looks pretty good
I also created this broken bridge as well as you saw in the previous video
and here you can see that I've made a rushing effect so though so I use the
glue just going towards the middle and rushing over the broken bits of wood so
I've based painted it as in video three and in video four and five it cited the
stonework and then we're going to apply just a straight blue onto the tile and
use boots of speed just to speed it up so you can see it being done and you
will see some of the undercoat does start to show through so just give it a
good good coating don't worry about the other coat going through because we're
going to do several layers of paint this is merely just to get the first prime of
blue and just give it a good good mix around there so then into the blues
straight in again we're going to mix some white and mix it up with your brush
and then go over while the others are still wet and start to swirl it around
just to get a sort of a swirl look in the water again we will go over this
again so it doesn't need to be a hundred percent perfect just to get the effect
going so I've let it dry and now I'm going to water down the same blue we had
there and begin to apply the water down like light cyan and sort of color to the
tile remember this was allowed to dry so again boots of speed just to speed it
up and again you can see now we're not able to see too much of that undercoat
underneath the tile anymore and which is building up layers and layers cleaning
off the brush so now I'll just use a sponge to sponge off the excess water
and then we can continue on with the next so I'm going to put some more blue
back in there and then I'm just going to put little patches of blue and from the
deep areas where the pylons will be and just circle the brush out again just
have the effect of sort of the shadowy darker areas in the water where the
objects may be underwater so that's where the pylons will be and just using
boots of speed again and then what we'll do is we will apply paint down the sides
where the walls are again just to simulate what the you know the the depth
of the water and really all so that there there is you know wall underneath
the water as well just to give it that sort of 3d look on a 2d surface this is
the beauty of 2.5 DS you can make something look more three-dimensional
that it actually is especially if you're if you're you doing a three layer rule
like I do so you don't go above three layers very handy to do little bits of
shading and things like that to give it a better look so in that vein I now just
add a little dab of black into the weather pylons are going to be and just
swirl around again just to sort of add some depth to are those areas so the
first one I did there it probably needs a little bit more blue just to take it
back again it's a bit too grey so I'll just wash the black off the brush and
then just go over it again with a little bit of blue just to bring it back again
so you see it's starting to take shape now let's get the area of the water
still not quite there so what we're going to do now is just let that dry has
dried now and with boots of speed I'm just adding white to a wider brush I'm
just going to drag that over the ripples just to sort of bring them out into the
foreground so that it really shows off the ripples that are there and that's
what really sells it so I've allowed that to dry and then you've got the
bridge so you can see you know it's a nice looking sort of effect with the
pylons there so now to attach the bridge I just add hot glue to where the pylons
be just be careful the hot glue is hot hence the name and you need to sort of
do this relatively quickly because you don't want the glue to to harden so the
hot glue you must be quite hot so let the hot glue gun stand for a while so
that does take time to cool that'll allow you to do all four and then place
the bridge of course you know with different different things that may be a
different way that you do it but just bear in mind how quickly the hot glue
will actually harden so that hardens very very fast and there we have the
bridge so what we do now is we're going to grab some high gloss varnish this is
a water black based high gloss varnish this is similar to what DMC Scotty uses
I'm just going to apply that directly over the over the paintwork and that
will dry to quite a glossy wet look now I've left I didn't do this prior to
attaching the bridge really because I don't need to apply it onto the whole
tile so basically not using as much and it's not really going to reflect
underneath the bridge anyway but also just yeah that's the way that I do it so
I also as you can see paint just the first sort of tile segments and the
edges of the bridge with that as well so that just gives it a look of like water
has been splashing over the edges as you can see is the reflection here so what
has been splashing over the edges of the stonework and the actual bridge and you
can see in these close-ups sort of how the the gloss effect is working in there
and then detail on the bridge so that's how I paint water effects now as you can
